cyclone.name: LAURA
cyclone.current_location: about 50 miles north of the western tip of Cuba and about 765 miles southeast of Lake Charles, Louisiana
cyclone.trajectory: moving WNW across the southeastern Gulf today, turning northwest on Wednesday and aiming for the upper Texas–south-central Louisiana coast
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: near the Texas–Louisiana border (around Cameron LA / Port Arthur TX)

weather_observation.watch_coast: Morgan City, Louisiana to the Mouth of the Mississippi River
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Texas coast from High Island eastward through all of southern Louisiana including Mississippi River delta and adjacent bays
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (39-57 mph) are possible at the port beginning late Wednesday night and could last through Thursday morning; a brief period of stronger gusts cannot be ruled out if the storm tracks slightly east.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Water levels in the Lower Mississippi River, Lake Pontchartrain, and surrounding marshes could rise 3–5 ft if peak surge coincides with high tide.
weather_observation.rainfall: 4–8 inches of rain with locally higher totals up to 10 inches possible, leading to flash and urban flooding along the river terminals.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Brief tornadoes in outer rainbands and hazardous rip currents along adjacent barrier islands.
